title: U.S. Women's Hockey Team threatens championship boycott over wages dispute
text:
USA captain Meghan Duggan and her teammates want fair pay. Mark Humphrey/Associated Press 
Hilary Knight and the U.S. womenâs hockey team are taking a stand against unequal pay. 
Knight announced Wednesday in a statement on Twitter that she and her teammates will not be playing in the 2017Â IIHF World Championship unless âsignificant progressâ is made to settle a dispute with USA Hockey over unfair wages. 
US WNT will not play in 2017 World Championship due to stalled negotiations over fair wages and support from USA Hockey #BeBoldForChange pic.twitter.com/qEXVyoKE6y

Team USA players informed USA Hockey on Wednesday that they wonât report to training camp next week or play in the tournament, which begins March 31, unless a deal is reached, per ESPNW. 
âWe are asking for a living wage and for USA Hockey to fully support its programs for women and girls and stop treating us like an afterthought,â USA captain Meghan Duggan told ESPNW. âWe have represented our country with dignity and deserve to be treated with fairness and respect.â 
According to ESPNW, USA Hockey has paid the womenâs team just $1,000 per month during the six-month residency period at the Winter Olympics and âvirtually nothingâ over the rest of that four-year period, meaning the women earn roughly $6,000 over a four-year span despite being asked to train full time. 
USA Hockey claimed in a statement that itâs prepared to pay each player much higher wages at the 2018 Winter Olympics, providing nearly $85,000 in cash for each player through âadditional support stipends and medal incentives.â ButÂ John B. Langel, an attorney who is representingÂ the U.S. women in contract negotiations, balked at that number. 
âThat is so incredibly misleading, and you can quote me on that,â Langel told ESPNW. âThat couples the (U.S. Olympic Committee) money with their (federation) money and assumes the women win gold at the 2018 Olympics. That amount would only apply to the Olympic year. And more than $60,000 of it would come from the USOC.â 
According to the players, USA Hockey also spends roughly $3.5 million on a national team development program for men, but thereâs no comparable program for women. 
USA Hockey says it still plans to field a âcompetitive teamâ if Knight and her teammates follow through on the boycott. 
âGood luck getting a suitable No. 1 competition to represent our country on a world stage,â Knight said. âI kind of dare them.â
